title: Thank you Always for acknowledging it isn’t just women who bleed
text:
Periods can be uncomfortable for many but being trans adds many additional layers (Picture: Education Images/Universal Images Group via Getty Images)

I’m so, so glad that Always has listened to the voices of the trans, non-binary and intersex community (let’s not forget the allies too – thank you) and removed the Venus symbol from their sanitary pad wrapping.

They are adapting their business to better cater for people who bleed and let’s be honest, this issue doesn’t just affect women. Those that believe that don’t live in the 21st century.

Periods can be uncomfortable for many but being trans adds many additional layers.

I was diagnosed with gender dysphoria at 14. I’d leave my house hoping nobody would call me ‘she’ as my heart would drop – every single time.

I’d catch a glance of myself in the mirror and I wouldn’t recognise myself so I’d try and convince myself that this body was temporary. Looking at it was a complete no-no.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The physical fight wasn’t enjoyable but the mental pain… the places in which my brain took me are indescribable.

A year later I experienced my first period. I felt confused, like my own body had betrayed me, like my body was fighting my mind. My body dysphoria heightened severely to the point that I could no longer look in mirrors.

For me, having periods caused my mental health to spiral to a new low – a place where no 15-year-old should be. Being a transgender man having a bodily function that was solely associated with cis-gender women was torture.

Physically, my periods caused me to pass out and act out of character as I didn’t feel like me. Each month I lost a little bit more of my dignity.

I really struggled with buying period products – I felt embarrassed because I didn’t believe I should have been buying them in the first place. I’d ask my mum or sister to buy them for me and if they couldn’t, I’d order them online.

From time to time I came on early and there was no other option but to buy them myself, from a shop, in public. I remember strolling down the female hygiene aisle, feeling distraught, walking slowly enough that no one would see the little boy buying sanitary pads.

I know I could have been buying them for anybody – but I knew they were for me and that was the agonising part. I’d keep my head down and pick out the first product I found that seemed remotely suitable.

I remember strolling down the female hygiene aisle, feeling distraught, walking slowly enough that no one would see the little boy buying sanitary pads.

I cannot understand why people are now so bothered about Always removing the Venus logo.

Advertisement

Advertisement

It is not an attack on women, it’s not denying the existence of women, nor is it an attempt to erase them. It’s an opportunity to become inclusive, which in my opinion has no impact on women.

What it will do is remove some of the discomfort and stigma associated around trans, non-binary and intersex individuals who have to buy and use these products.

Taking the Venus sign off the packaging doesn’t make the product defective and it doesn’t affect its functionality.

And let’s think beyond the trans/non-binary/intersex communities for a moment – not every woman wants pretty pink packaging with gendered, hologram prints to remind them of their gender.

My biggest concern is that gendering products forces people to continue living up to the expectations of gender roles, which they may not feel are applicable to them.

Some men are flamboyant, some women are masculine, and that’s simply who they are. Not everyone who gets a period is a woman, and not every woman gets a period, so we need to stop hinging ‘femininity’ on menstruation.

I’m also bored of seeing my community being attacked. How I identify is not a choice and what body functions I should experience aren’t up for debate.

I don’t imagine global companies make branding decisions overnight and responding to Metro.co.uk, Always said that they made the change ‘after hearing from many people across genders and age groups.’

Advertisement

It shows this must have been a calculated decision, based on the wants and needs of consumers – and I’m happy that Always have committed to change. No form of labelling, speech or advertisement should come at the cost of making another human being feeling dysphoric.

In the future, gender neutral sanitary options could make all the difference for young people trying to come to terms with their identities, while simultaneously dealing with the added hardships brought on by puberty.

For me, it might have been the difference between feeling alone and dysphoric, and being able to accept that periods were a normal part of my existence. It would have made me feel seen, knowing that a brand had me and my community in mind. 15-year-old me would have really appreciated it.

Until then, this is still a massive step towards further inclusion and Always, I commend you. Although I believe inclusivity and diversity should be the standard, when a company sides with the minority it deserves recognition.

Trans people won’t be erased, non-binary people won’t be erased, intersex people won’t be erased.

In fact, the world is just starting to make space for us and everyone who opposes the attempt to invalidate our existence is bound to fail.
